text: Welcome to Exploring Computing.

Today's video is
"Webpage Layout--
Overview of Layout Techniques."

So in this video,
we're going to take

a look at four different ways
to lay out your webpages.

Two of these are currently
in widespread use.

One of them is there
for historic reasons,

and to compare to
our fourth method,

and to highlight what's really
great about the fourth method.

And then the fourth method is
the future of webpage layout,

but probably isn't
as widely used yet
as the middle two techniques.

I'm actually going to recommend
you use the fourth technique,

unless you've got a
good reason not to.
So let's take a look at these.

So the first technique
is table-based layout.
This is no longer in use.

But as I said, by comparing
table-based layout

to our fourth method,
grid-based layout,

you're going to really see
what the advantage of using

cascading style sheets is
and why grid-based layout is
a great way to go.

The second technique
we're going to talk about
is float-based layout.

This has been, for many,
many years, the most widely
used technique out there.
I just did a quick spot check.

And for example,
the Washington Post

is using float-based
layout right now.

Our third technique,
Flexbox layout,

has picked up a
little bit of momentum

in the last maybe
three years or so.

I don't think it's
a great choice.
It's good to know about.

And the techniques
used in Flexbox

are going to be useful
for a variety of purposes.

But I don't really think
you should use this
as your main layout technique.

That was not the
intention originally
when it was developed.
People have used it as a hack.
I don't think it's the best.

I really do think this last
one, the grid-based layout,
is definitely the way to go.

But the two most commonly
used techniques right now

are float-based layout
and Flexbox layout.

So if you come on to
an existing webpage,

those are the two techniques
you're most likely to run into.

The other thing
to be aware of is

that one of the reasons
why grid-based layout, even

though it's really great,
isn't in widespread usage

yet is that it's only been
recently that all the web
browsers are supporting it.

And at this point,
about 95% of the web
browsers out there support it.

So you may still run into a few
web browsers that can't use it.

Flexbox layout has
about 97% support.

And then float-based layout and
table-based layout everybody
can use.

But don't use
table-based layout.
OK.

We're going to go over three
examples for each of these four

techniques to give us a
chance to see how they work.

I'm not actually going to be
showing you any HTML or CSS
in this particular video.

But we will take
an extensive look

at grid layout in
the next video.

And then for the
CS105 students, we're

going to have a
full lecture where

we look at a bunch
of different examples

and I recreate parts of the New
York Times website and parts

of the Washington Post website
using grid-based layout,

so you can get a real good
feel for how it all works.
OK.

So our first example is going
to be this simple three column
webpage right here.

And then we're
going to take a look

at this webpage that has a mix
of different column formats.

So we'll have three
columns up at the top

and two columns
down at the bottom.

And then finally,
our last example

is going to have a
rather mixed layout

here, where it's not like
there's two columns at the top
and three on the bottom.
It's really a jumble.

And so we'll see how each of
the different layout techniques

handles each of
these three cases.
All right.

So table-based layout is based
on the concept of tables.

And so tables have been
in HTML from the start.

We talked previously
about how HTML came out

of physics, the CERN physics
consortium in Europe.

And they were trying to
exchange physics papers.

And one of the things that you
need for physics is tables.

So we've had tables
from the start.

So basically, for quite a
while, we used these tables
to layout our webpages.

And I'll talk a little
bit later about why
this isn't the best approach.

So let's say I want to go ahead
and reproduce my three column
website.
How can I do this?

Well, if you think about it,
this three column website

is just a table where there's
one row and three columns.

So it's actually
really straightforward

recreating this using
table-based layout.

And then we've
got our table here

with different top
and bottom sections.
All right.

So there's a couple
of ways to do this.

So one thing that you can do
is you can nest your tables.

So we have one table which
consists of a single column
and two rows.

And then within
that first table,

you have another table, which
is a three column one row table.

And then at the bottom, you
have a two column one row table.

Or you could have a
single table where you
have four columns and two rows.

And then you can take advantage
of the column span attribute

to get some of your elements to
span across multiple columns.

So each of these
approaches will work fine.

And then finally, we have
this mix layout here.

And so again, I
think the easiest way

to think about this is
to think of nesting.

And so one of the
things that's going

to occur with all
of these techniques
is you can use nesting.

So you could say, oh, I'm going
to go ahead and treat this

as a layout where I have
a column on the left
and a column on the right.

And then you can go
in and say, well,

in that column on the right,
I need to lay that out.

And so you can do a
separate internal layout
for the right column.

And that's a good way of
going about these things.

So I can think of
this whole thing

is I have a two
column one row table.

And then on the right
column, I could say, inside

of that table, I actually
have another table.

And that table is one
column and two rows.

And then you can take
it a further level.

And you could say, and
the second row actually

contains another table, which
is two columns and one row.
And this all works.

But this is actually
one of the reasons

why we aren't really doing
table layout anymore.

And that is, as you
start nesting the tables,

it becomes more and
more computation

expensive and
slower to do layout.

So generally, three layers
of tables was just fine.

But once you started
getting four, or five,

or six layers of tables, it
started getting kind of messy.

And the web browsers were
not very happy with it.

There are other reasons why
this isn't the best approach.

Although, some of
these issues will also

crop up with the next
two techniques as well.
OK.

So instead of treating this
as a table nested inside

of a table nested
inside of a table,

you could also treat
this as a three column

two row table and then use
row span and column span.
And that could work as well.

And depending on what
you were trying to do,

one of these or the other
one might work better.

But we're not going to worry
about that in this video.

Either of these
techniques would work.

So what are the issues
with table-based layout?

Well, one of the biggest
issues is that the tables
are in our HTML.

So when we create
our HTML, we are

defining what our layout
looks like in the HTML.

And so we're really
locking ourselves
into a particular layout.

And if we wanted to
change the layout

at a later point
in time-- let's say

I wanted to change
the layout for all
the webpages on my website.

I would need to go in and
modify each of the HTML files

because the HTML files
have the layout encoded

in the tables in
those HTML files

instead of being separated
out from our cascading style
sheets.

Remember, that's why
we said we really

want to have the presentation
information of a cascading

style sheet, so I can modify
the cascading style sheet

and it instantly changes all
the webpages on our website.

And that doesn't
work with tables.

And in fact, we're
going to discover

it doesn't work with the
next two techniques either.

And then as I mentioned,
the nested tables

can become
computationally expensive.
OK.

So we used the table-based
layout for many, many years.

But when we started using
cascading style sheets,

another technique
came into the fore.

And that's this
float-based layout.

And float-based layout is
still used quite a bit.

And you will run into
many websites that
are using float-based layout.

So how does float-based
layout work?

Well, the first thing
to remind ourselves
is, what is this idea of float?

And so we've talked about
float before in this class.
We talked about floating images.

So here on the left, I've
got an image of Venice.
I've floated it to the left.

And then I've got text
alongside it on the right.

And then we did this
example, where we had images
with captions underneath it.

And in that case, I wasn't
actually floating the image.

I was actually
floating some divs,

with a div containing both
the image and the caption
underneath it.

But again, we would float
those to the left or the right.

And as I mentioned
very briefly when

we were talking about float,
you can float any block level
element.

And so here, I've
got a blockquote.

And I've floated the
blockquote to the left.

And you can see it's
doing the exact same thing

that our images did
when we flooded them
to the left or the right.

And so we can actually
float multiple images.

And that will actually stack
the images next to each other.

If I float two images to
the left, assuming they fit,

they will end up right
next to each other.

And I can do the same thing
here with these blockquotes.

So what I've done here is I've
added a second blockquote.

And I've told both the block
quest to float to the left.

And they've ended up
right next to each other.

Just as our original
had a single blockquote,

we floated that to the left,
now we've got two blockquotes

and we've floated
those both to the left.

And if you think about what
these two blockquotes are doing

here floated to the left, well,
those are essentially columns.

And so I can get rid of the text
other than the two blockquotes.
And this is what I have.
And so I have two columns.

And if you've looked
at any webpage,

they all are composed
of different columns.

So this is really
the key to laying out
webpages using floats.

We go ahead and create
these different columns.
And we float them to the left.
And so I was using blockquotes.

I can replace the
blockquotes with divs.

And you can put basically
any renderable element
inside of a div.

So here, I've got two divs,
both floated to the left.

And so if we go to
our three examples,

if I want to let
my three columns,

I just go ahead and
create three divs.

And then I float each
of the divs to the left.

It is possible to mix
floating to the left
and floating to the right.

But that gets messy
in certain situations.

It can also be useful
in certain situations.

But if you just float
everything on the left,

you can basically create
any webpage consisting
of different columns.
OK.

So what about our
example where we

have a mix of three columns on
the top and two on the bottom?
How am I going to handle this?

Well, what you're going
to do is you're first

going to divide the
webpage into two divs.

And these are just
standard divs.

And the standard behavior of
a div followed by another div

is to stack the two divs
on top of each other.

And then what we're
going to do is

they're going to put
a bunch of divs inside
of one of those standard divs.

And instead of just using the
standard behavior of the div,

we're going to float
those to the left,

just as we did a
little bit earlier.

And then we'll do the
same thing on the bottom.

We'll create two divs
down at the bottom.

And we'll float both
those to the left as well.

And we'll actually get
what we're expecting here,
what we're looking for here.

It does turn out there's
a bit of messiness,

which I'm going to completely
ignore for this discussion.

If you do want to use
float-based layout,

the benefit of using
the float-based being

that it does work
in 100% of the web

browsers out there, whereas
our next to two techniques,

you'll recall that the
next technique works

in 97% of the web browsers
and the final technique only

works in 95% of
the web browsers,

float-based will
work on all of them.
OK.

So what about our
mixed example here?

Well, again, what we want to do
is we want to think of a nest.
So I'm going two divs here.

And I'm going to float
both the divs to the left.

And that's going to give me
this concept of two columns.
So I've got one column.
I've got the red column.

And then I have the
light blue column.

And then in the
light blue column,
I'm going to create two divs.

And remember, if you've
got divs and you're not

floating the divs, that stacks
the divs on top of each other.

So I've got these two divs
stacked on top of each other.

And then the bottom
div, I'm going
to put another two divs in.

I'm going to float
those both to the left.

And that's how I get
the cell to work.

So the issue with
float-based layout

is it's still pretty
tied to the HTML.

So in order to get these
columns floated to the left,

I need to create the divs
in exactly the right manner,

so I can move the elements
in a particular way

such that they do stack
up next to each other.

So it turns out that my
HTML still is very closely
tied to the layout.

You can't just change
the CSS and have
a completely new webpage.
You can make some changes.

But for the most part, the HTML,
and the divs that you choose,

and how you place
the divs is going

to really drive how the webpage
appears in the web browser.

There's also some
messy issues which

I'm completely
ignoring here in order

to get all these divs
to work properly.
They can certainly be handled.

There are techniques
to handle them.

But it's not quite
as clean as I may

have led you to believe
in our discussion here.

But nevertheless, this
technique is very widely used

and has been the
main technique used
on webpages for quite a while.

Now, the next technique uses
something called Flexbox.

So let's start off by talking
a little bit about what Flexbox
is.

So Flexbox is designed
to take a bunch of divs

that are contained
inside a parent div

and to control what those
inner divs look like.

So one of the key
things that you

can do with those
inner child divs

is you can control
whether or not
they appear in a row or column.
So here, I've got a row of divs.

And then I can just easily
change it to a column of divs

just by changing one
style sheet property.

And there's some fancy
things you can do as well.

So here, I'm actually
showing the parent divs.

So I've got A, B, C, and D
contained within a parent dive.
So A, B, C, and D are divs.

And they're contained
in a parent div.

And so you can see I can
move the divs to the left.
I can move them to the right.
I can move to the middle.
I can spread them out.

And so these are
all different things

that you can do very easily
just by changing a style sheet
property.

You can also say, hey,
if the divs fit, great.

If they don't fit,
I want to wrap.

Or you could say,
if they don't fit,

I want you to squeeze
them in there.

And so there's different
things that you
can do with the child divs.

You can select
certain child divs

and say, hey, if we've
got the extra space,

I want that to
expand out to take

the maximum amount
of space available.

And you can play
with the alignment.

So if you think about
what we've seen so far,

you may be wondering,
how does that--
that seems useful.

But that doesn't really
seem to lay out webpages.

And that certainly was
the original intention.

The intention was that Flexbox
layout was not designed
to actually lay out webpages.

I think what happened was
people were really sick
of a float-based layout.
And it was messy.

And you had to add in all
this extra stuff in your HTML.
And Flexbox layout came along.

And people were like, great,
I'm just going to use it.

Maybe this isn't what it
was originally intended for.
But I'm going to use it anyway.

So what was Flexbox layout
actually intended for?

Well, Flexbox and
grid-based layout,

which is going to be our
last technique-- both Flexbox

and grid were defined at
roughly the same time.

And the idea was
that you were going

to use a mix of grid
layout and Flexbox layout
to lay out your webpages.

The grid layout was going to be
used for the major components

and figuring out how
everything overall
was going to fit together.

And you could use Flexbox
for smaller components.
So what do I mean by that?

Well, here I've got a screenshot

And you can see on the

I've got a bunch of
different opinions.

And the overall
look of the webpage

And then so here's

where we've got this
center section called

And again, overall webpage

And then the "For

that could be a little bit

And so we haven't
really talked about it.

But among other things,
Flexbox could also

be used to set different
ordering of elements.

So let's say they knew that
you really like chocolate.

And there were a bunch of
recipes and one of them
was chocolate.

They could tweak the style
sheet using JavaScript

and put the chocolate
recipes at the top.

And so this is the sort of thing
that you could do with Flexbox.
So again, Flexbox is useful.

I certainly am not
suggesting that,

if you're going to go
off and create a webpage,

that you shouldn't

But as far as Flexbox being used
for the entire webpage layout,

I don't think it's
the ideal choice.
OK.

So let's take a look at how

So if we've got our
three columns here,

so this is pretty
straightforward.

I need an outer div

And then inside

For our messier

children are also

And they will be

So I can do this on

So that that works.

And then for our mixed
example here, again, I'm

going to go with
this idea of nesting.
And so I've got the outer div.
And it has two children.
And those are laid out in rows.

And then the second

The second child

The issues involved
here are we're still

We can do some things where

And we can change the direction.

So this actually could

if you think about if I've

that's going to

So you can do some

OK.

So we've got our last

In grid layout, we break
